head.title: Frobenius-Perron Resonances for Maps with a Mixed Phase Space

article.h1: Frobenius-Perron Resonances for Maps with a Mixed Phase Space

span.span: Joachim Weber11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{1}, Fritz Haake11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{1}, and Petr Å eba22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2}
11NUMBER:11 Fachbereich Physik, UniversitÃ¤t-GH Essen, 45117 Essen, Germany
22NUMBER:22 Institute of Physics, Czech Academy of Sciences, Prague, Czech Republic

div.p: Resonances of the time evolution (Frobenius-Perron) operator ğ’«ğ’«caligraphic-P{\cal P} for phase space densities have recently been shown to play a key role for the interrelations of classical, semiclassical and quantum dynamics. Efficient methods to determine resonances are thus in demand, in particular for Hamiltonian systems displaying a mix of chaotic and regular behavior. We present a powerful method based on truncating ğ’«ğ’«caligraphic-P{\cal P} to a finite matrix which not only allows to identify resonances but also the associated phase space structures. It is demonstrated to work well for a prototypical dynamical system.

Effectively irreversible behavior of classical Hamiltonian systems can be elucidated by studying the phase space density and its propagator, the Frobenius-Perron operator ğ’«ğ’«caligraphic-P{\cal P}. Due to Liouvilleâ€™s theorem ğ’«ğ’«caligraphic-P{\cal P} can be represented by an infinite unitary matrix whose spectrum lies on the unit circle in the complex plane. Nevertheless, means and correlation functions of observables can relax (see figure 1c) with damping factors known as (Ruelle-Pollicott) resonances [1, 2, 3, 4] of ğ’«ğ’«caligraphic-P{\cal P}. These resonances have recently attracted attention, e.g. in a superanalytic approach to universal fluctuations in quantum (quasi-) energy spectra which originated from the physics of disordered systems. In that approach the Frobenius-Perron resonances constitute a link between classical and quantum chaos [5, 6]. There is even a recent experiment where quantum fingerprints of Ruelle-Pollicott resonances are identified [7]. To further clarify the interrelations between classical, semiclassical, and quantum behavior, a practical scheme to actually determine classical resonances is called for which is free of restrictions of previous investigations, like hyperbolicity, one-dimensional (quasi-) phase space or isolation of the phase-space regions causing intermittency.

Our thus motivated quantitative investigations into Hamiltonian systems with mixed phase space, a still largely unexplored area of great interest and promise, lead us to the discrete unimodular Frobenius-Perron eigenvalues (with eigenfunctions localized in islands of regular motion around elliptic periodic orbits, see figure 1a) and to resonances, smaller than unity in modulus (with eigenfunctions localized on the unstable manifolds of hyperbolic periodic orbits, see figure 2a-c). Both the discrete spectrum and the resonances are determined by diagonalizing truncated Frobenius-Perron matrices ğ’«(N)superscriptğ’«ğ‘caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)} and studying the cut-off dependence of its eigenvalues. Using the information about eigenfunctions, we then reproduce resonances by the so-called cycle expansion of periodic-orbit theory and furthermore through decay rates of correlation functions. We should add that similarly motivated but technically different (not involving eigenfunctions and employing external noise) efforts to determine resonances can be found in Refs.Â [8, 9, 10].

As a prototypical dynamical system we have employed the kicked top, i.e. a periodically kicked angular momentum Jâ†’=(jâ¢sinâ¡Î¸â¢cosâ¡Ï†,jâ¢sinâ¡Î¸â¢sinâ¡Ï†,jâ¢cosâ¡Î¸)â†’ğ½ğ‘—ğœƒğœ‘ğ‘—ğœƒğœ‘ğ‘—ğœƒOVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-J ARG:end RELOP:equals OPEN:( italic-j TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-theta TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-varphi PUNCT:, italic-j TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-theta TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-varphi PUNCT:, italic-j TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-theta CLOSE:)\vec{J}=(j\sin\theta\cos\varphi,j\sin\theta\sin\varphi,j\cos\theta) of conserved length jğ‘—italic-jj whose phase space is the sphere Jâ†’2/j2=1superscriptâ†’ğ½2superscriptğ‘—21OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-J ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-j POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\vec{J}^{2}/j^{2}=1; we confront a single degree of freedom with the â€œazimutalâ€ angle Ï•italic-Ï•italic-phi\phi as the coordinate and the cosine of the â€œpolarâ€ angle Î¸ğœƒitalic-theta\theta the conjugate momentum. The dynamics is specified as a stroboscopic area preserving map Mğ‘€italic-MM on phase space. It consists of rotations Rzâ¢(Î²z),Ryâ¢(Î²y)subscriptğ‘…ğ‘§subscriptğ›½ğ‘§subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¦subscriptğ›½ğ‘¦italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:, italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)R_{z}(\beta_{z}),R_{y}(\beta_{y}) about the y-limit-fromğ‘¦italic-y ADDOP:minusy- and z-limit-fromğ‘§italic-z ADDOP:minusz-axes and a â€œtorsionâ€, i.e. a nonlinear rotation Rzâ¢(Ï„â¢cosâ¡Î¸)subscriptğ‘…ğ‘§ğœğœƒitalic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-tau TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-theta CLOSE:)R_{z}(\tau\cos\theta) about the z-limit-fromğ‘§italic-z ADDOP:minusz-axis which changes Ï†ğœ‘italic-varphi\varphi by Ï„â¢cosâ¡Î¸ğœğœƒitalic-tau TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-theta\tau\cos\theta,

div.p: The equivalent map of the phase space density ÏğœŒitalic-rho\rho is brought about by the Frobenius-Perron operator ğ’«ğ’«caligraphic-P{\cal P},

div.p: We keep Î²z=Î²y=1subscriptğ›½ğ‘§subscriptğ›½ğ‘¦1italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\beta_{z}=\beta_{y}=1 fixed and vary the torsion constant Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau, starting with the integrable case Ï„=0ğœ0italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\tau=0. Increasing values of Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau bring about more and more chaos until for Ï„>10ğœ10italic-tau RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:10\tau>10 elliptic islands have become so small that they are difficult to detect. We shall focus on Ï„=4ğœ4italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:4\tau=4 (roughly 90%percent90NUMBER:90 POSTFIX:percent90\% of the phase space dominated by chaos) and Ï„=10ğœ10italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:10\tau=10 (more than 99%percent99NUMBER:99 POSTFIX:percent99\% chaos).

A Hilbert space of phase space functions on the sphere is spanned by the spherical harmonics Ylâ¢mâ¢(Î¸,Ï†)subscriptğ‘Œğ‘™ğ‘šğœƒğœ‘italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-l italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-theta PUNCT:, italic-varphi CLOSE:)Y_{lm}(\theta,\varphi) with l=0,1,2,â€¦ğ‘™012â€¦italic-l RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, ID:dotsl=0,1,2,\dots and |m|â‰¤lğ‘šğ‘™VERTBAR:| italic-m VERTBAR:| RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-l|m|\leq l. These functions are ordered with respect to phase space resolution by the index lğ‘™italic-ll: if all Ylâ¢msubscriptğ‘Œğ‘™ğ‘šitalic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-l italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:endY_{lm} with 0â‰¤lâ‰¤lmâ¢aâ¢x0ğ‘™subscriptğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥NUMBER:0 RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-l RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end0\leq l\leq l_{max} are admitted phase space structures of area roughly 4â¢Ï€/(lmâ¢aâ¢x+1)24ğœ‹superscriptsubscriptğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥12NUMBER:4 italic-pi MULOP:divide OPEN:( italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end4\pi/(l_{max}+1)^{2} can be resolved. If we so truncate the infinite Frobenius-Perron matrix ğ’«lâ¢m,lâ€²â¢mâ€²subscriptğ’«ğ‘™ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘™â€²superscriptğ‘šâ€²caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-l italic-m PUNCT:, italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-m POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\cal P}_{lm,l^{\prime}m^{\prime}}, we (i) destroy unitarity, (ii) restrict the spectrum to N=(lmâ¢aâ¢x+1)2ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥12italic-N RELOP:equals OPEN:( italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endN=(l_{max}+1)^{2} discrete eigenvalues whose moduli cannot exceed unity, and (iii) renounce the resolution of phase space structures of linear dimension below 4â¢Ï€/(lmâ¢aâ¢x+1)4ğœ‹subscriptğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥1italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:4 italic-pi ARG:end MULOP:divide OPEN:( italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:)\sqrt{4\pi}/(l_{max}+1). Upon diagonalizing the truncated NÃ—Nğ‘ğ‘italic-N MULOP:times italic-NN\times N\,matrix ğ’«(N)superscriptğ’«ğ‘caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)} and increasing Nğ‘italic-NN we find the â€œnewly bornâ€ eigenvalues close to the origin while the â€œolderâ€ ones move about in the complex plane. â€œVery oldâ€ ones eventually settle for good. If the classical dynamics is integrable (Ï„=0ğœ0italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\tau=0 or Î²y=0subscriptğ›½ğ‘¦0italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\beta_{y}=0), the asymptotic large-Nğ‘ADDOP:minus italic-N-N loci are back to the unit circle, where the full ğ’«ğ’«caligraphic-P{\cal P} has its spectrum. But not so for a mixed phase space: while some eigenvalues of ğ’«(N)superscriptğ’«ğ‘caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)} â€œfreezeâ€ with unit moduli, others come to rest inside the unit circle as Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘italic-N ARROW:to ID:infinityN\to\infty. Table 1 illustrates how non-unimodular eigenvalues found for the kicked top with Ï„=10ğœ10italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:10\tau=10 at lmâ¢aâ¢x=40subscriptğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥40italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:40l_{max}=40 remain in their positions as lmâ¢aâ¢xsubscriptğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endl_{max} is increased to lmâ¢aâ¢x=50,60subscriptğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥5060italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:50 PUNCT:, NUMBER:60l_{max}=50,60 and 7070NUMBER:7070.

We could pass over such findings and speak of the danger of tampering with infinity, were there not good reasons for and a physical interpretation of the existence of such stable non-unimodular eigenvalues.

The following qualitative argument suggests the persistence of non-unimodular eigenvalues as Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘italic-N ARROW:to ID:infinityN\to\infty for non-integrable dynamics. In contrast to regular motion, chaos brings about a hierarchy of phase space structures which extends without end to ever finer scales. A truncated Frobenius-Perron operator ğ’«(N)superscriptğ’«ğ‘caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)} must reflect the flow of probability towards the unresolved scales as a loss, however large the cut-off Nğ‘italic-NN may be chosen.

Arguments from perturbation theory [13, 14] indicate that any non-unitary approximation to a unitary operator with continuous spectrum has some eigenvalues in positions near (non-unimodular) resonances of the unitary operator, i.e. poles of the resolvent in a higher Riemannian sheet. The perturbation series for such an eigenvalue does not converge but produces, with increasing order, a sequence of points concentrated in the neighborhood of the respective resonance. It is intuitive to interpret the freezing of non-unimodular eigenvalues (which need not be a strict convergence) as analogous to the â€œspectral concentrationâ€ known from perturbation theory.

To find further evidence for our interpretation of frozen eigenvalues as resonances we have looked at the eigenfunctions of ğ’«(N)superscriptğ’«ğ‘caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)}, with the following salient results. Eigenvalues freezing with unit moduli have eigenfunctions located on elliptic islands of regular motion surrounding elliptic periodic orbits in phase space. Such islands are bounded by invariant tori which form impenetrable barriers in phase space. We can thus expect the function constant inside the elliptic islands around a p-limit-fromğ‘italic-p ADDOP:minusp-periodic orbit and zero outside to be an eigenfunction of ğ’«ğ’«caligraphic-P{\cal P} with eigenvalue unity. Similarly reasoning we expect, for p>1ğ‘1italic-p RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:1p>1, the pğ‘italic-ppth roots of unity to arise as eigenvalues as well; their eigenfunctions should have constant moduli and be invariant under ğ’«psuperscriptğ’«ğ‘caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{p}. For the kicked top with Ï„=4ğœ4italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:4\tau=4 and lmâ¢aâ¢x=60subscriptğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥60italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:60l_{max}=60 an eigenfunction with the eigenvalue 0.99930.9993NUMBER:0.99930.9993, i.Â e. almost at unity, is shown in figure 1a. It is localized on the three islands around an elliptic orbit of period three (see figure 1b) and does have the two expected partners. We have indeed found frozen eigenvalues near the pğ‘italic-pp-th roots of unity and their eigenfunctions localized near elliptic period-pğ‘italic-pp orbits for pğ‘italic-pp up to 6; without much further effort such signatures of higher periods could be identified.

Now on to the eigenvalues freezing with moduli smaller than unity. Once such freezing has been observed the corresponding eigenfunction has approached its final shape on the resolved phase space scales. The eigenfunctions are sharply localized around unstable manifolds of hyperbolic periodic orbits, ones with low periods at first since these are easiest to resolve; but with growing lmâ¢aâ¢xsubscriptğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endl_{max} more complex orbits of higher periods appear in the â€œsupportâ€ of eigenfunctions. Even though all periodic orbits contributing to the structure of an eigenfunction have similar stability coefficients and even though the latter do describe the rate of mutual departure of neighboring trajectories it would be too naive to simply identify resonances with stability coefficients; we shall rather have to resort to cycle expansions further below.

Just as for the eigenvalues there is no strict convergence of the eigenfunctions. With increasing resolution new structures on finer scales become visible, in correspondence with the infinitely convoluted shape of the unstable manifolds (see figure 2a-b). Since no finite approximation ğ’«(N)superscriptğ’«ğ‘caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)} accounts for arbitrarily fine structures one encounters the aforementioned loss of probability from resolved to unresolved scales. Not even in the limit Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘italic-N ARROW:to ID:infinityN\to\infty can the unitarity of ğ’«ğ’«caligraphic-P{\cal P} be restored: rather, the eigenfunctions tend to singular objects outside the Hilbert space, in tune with a continuous spectrum of ğ’«ğ’«caligraphic-P\cal P.

The reader may have noticed that all eigenvalues in table 1 are real or almost imaginary. In fact, all eigenvalues we have identified as frozen inside the unit circle have phases corresponding to those of roots of unity, a fact demanding explanation. Clearly, since ğ’«(N)superscriptğ’«ğ‘caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)} is real the eigenvalues are either real or come in complex conjugate pairs, but no other phase than zero is distinguished by that argument. Again, the eigenfunctions offer further clues. We find that the phases of the complex eigenvalues are determined by the length pğ‘italic-pp of the shortest periodic orbit present in an eigenfunction fğ‘“italic-ff as those of the pğ‘italic-pp-th roots of unity. The following intuitive argument indicates that this is to be expected.

Assume an eigenfunction is mostly concentrated around a shortest unstable orbit with period pğ‘italic-pp as well as a longer one with period pâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endp^{\prime}. Denote by Î´p,nsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘ğ‘›italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p PUNCT:, italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta_{p,n} a â€œcharacteristic functionâ€ which is constant near the nğ‘›italic-nn-th point of the period-pğ‘italic-pp orbit, n=1â¢â€¦â¢pğ‘›1â€¦ğ‘italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 ID:ldots italic-pn=1\ldots p, and zero elsewhere. The truncated Frobenius-Perron operator ğ’«(N)superscriptğ’«ğ‘caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)} maps Î´p,nsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘ğ‘›italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p PUNCT:, italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta_{p,n} into ğ’«(N)â¢Î´p,n=rpâ¢Î´p,n+1superscriptğ’«ğ‘subscriptğ›¿ğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘subscriptğ›¿ğ‘ğ‘›1caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p PUNCT:, italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p PUNCT:, italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)}\delta_{p,n}=r_{p}\delta_{p,n+1} with the real positive factor rpsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{p} smaller than unity accounting for losses, in particular to unresolved scales. Independent linear combinations of the Î´p,nsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘ğ‘›italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p PUNCT:, italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta_{p,n} can be formed as fpâ¢k=âˆ‘n=1pei2â¢Ï€â¢kâ¢n/pâ¢Î´p,nsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptei2ğœ‹ğ‘˜ğ‘›ğ‘subscriptğ›¿ğ‘ğ‘›italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start i2 italic-pi italic-k italic-n MULOP:divide italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p PUNCT:, italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:endf_{pk}=\sum_{n=1}^{p}{\rm e}^{{\rm i}2\pi kn/p}\delta_{p,n} with k=1â¢â€¦â¢pğ‘˜1â€¦ğ‘italic-k RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 ID:ldots italic-pk=1\ldots p. Now consider a sum of two such functions, g=fpâ¢k+fpâ€²â¢kâ€²ğ‘”subscriptğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“superscriptğ‘â€²superscriptğ‘˜â€²italic-g RELOP:equals italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-k POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:endg=f_{pk}+f_{p^{\prime}k^{\prime}}, and apply ğ’«(N)superscriptğ’«ğ‘caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)}. For gğ‘”italic-gg to qualify as an approximate eigenfunction we must obviously have rpâ‰ˆrpâ€²subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘subscriptğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘â€²italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:endr_{p}\approx r_{p^{\prime}} and k/p=kâ€²/pâ€²ğ‘˜ğ‘superscriptğ‘˜â€²superscriptğ‘â€²italic-k MULOP:divide italic-p RELOP:equals italic-k POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endk/p=k^{\prime}/p^{\prime}. But then indeed ğ’«(N)â¢gâ‰ˆrpâ¢ei2â¢Ï€â¢k/pâ¢gsuperscriptğ’«ğ‘ğ‘”subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘superscriptei2ğœ‹ğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘”caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-g RELOP:approximately-equals italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start i2 italic-pi italic-k MULOP:divide italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-g{\cal P}^{(N)}g\approx r_{p}{\rm e}^{{\rm i}2\pi k/p}g and [ğ’«(N)]pâ¢gâ‰ˆrppâ¢gsuperscriptdelimited-[]superscriptğ’«ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘ğ‘”OPEN:[ caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-g RELOP:approximately-equals italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-g[{\cal P}^{(N)}]^{p}g\approx r_{p}^{p}g. The phase is thus dictated by the shortest orbit. Needless to say, the argument is identical to the one used before for the eigenfunctions living in islands around elliptic orbits, save for rp=1subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘1italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1r_{p}=1 in those regular cases. Since orbits of low period are most likely to be resolved first, the eigenvalues found for lmâ¢aâ¢x=40subscriptğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥40italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:40l_{max}=40 in table 1 have phases according to p=1,2ğ‘12italic-p RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2p=1,2 and 44NUMBER:44.

Knowing which orbits are linked to a non-unimodular eigenvalue, we can adopt a cycle expansion to calculate decay rates from periodic orbits [11]. A cycle expansion of the spectral determinant, i.e. the characteristic polynomial of the Frobenius-Perron operator, allows for the calculation of resonances in hyperbolic system with high accuracy [12]. The spectral determinant is expressed in terms of the traces of the Frobenius-Perron operator Trâ¢ğ’«nTrsuperscriptğ’«ğ‘›Tr caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\rm Tr}\;{\cal P}^{n} as dâ¢(z)=âˆn=1âˆexpâ¡(-znnâ¢Trâ¢ğ’«n)ğ‘‘ğ‘§superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘›1superscriptğ‘§ğ‘›ğ‘›Trsuperscriptğ’«ğ‘›italic-d OPEN:( italic-z CLOSE:) RELOP:equals SUMOP:product POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-n ARG:end Tr caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)d(z)=\prod_{n=1}^{\infty}\exp\left(-\frac{z^{n}}{n}{\rm Tr}\;{\cal P}^{n}\right) and subsequently expanded as a finite polynomial up to some order nmâ¢aâ¢xsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{max}. Only the first nmâ¢aâ¢xsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{max} traces are required for the calculation of this polynomial. The traces Trâ¢ğ’«nTrsuperscriptğ’«ğ‘›Tr caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\rm Tr}\;{\cal P}^{n} are calculated by summing over hyperbolic periodic orbits of length nğ‘›italic-nn as Trâ¢ğ’«n=âˆ‘1|detâ¡(1-J)|Trsuperscriptğ’«ğ‘›11ğ½Tr caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals SUMOP:sum FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start VERTBAR:| LIMITOP:determinant OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-J CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| ARG:end{\rm Tr}\;{\cal P}^{n}=\sum\frac{1}{|\det(1-J)|} where the 2Ã—222NUMBER:2 MULOP:times NUMBER:22\times 2 matrix J=âˆ‚â¡Mnâ¢(X)/âˆ‚â¡Xğ½superscriptğ‘€ğ‘›ğ‘‹ğ‘‹italic-J RELOP:equals OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-M POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X CLOSE:) MULOP:divide OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-XJ=\partial M^{n}(X)/\partial X is the linearized map Mnsuperscriptğ‘€ğ‘›italic-M POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM^{n} evaluated at any of the points of a contributing period-nğ‘›italic-nn orbit and X=(cosâ¡Î¸,Ï†)ğ‘‹ğœƒğœ‘italic-X RELOP:equals OPEN:( TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-theta PUNCT:, italic-varphi CLOSE:)X=(\cos\theta,\varphi) the phase space point. The zeros of the polynomial which are insensitive against an increase of nmâ¢aâ¢xsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{max} are inverses of resonances.

The condition under which the ordinary cycle expansion of a spectral determinant converges is that all periodic orbits are hyperbolic and sufficiently unstable [2, 11, 12]. But if we only consider one ergodic region in phase space at a time, i.e. bar contributions from elliptic orbits, and impose a stability bound by including only the relatively few hyperbolic orbits identified in an eigenfunction of ğ’«(N)superscriptğ’«ğ‘caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)}, we can still use the cycle expansion as follows.We assume the spectral determinant factorized as dâ¢(z)=âˆi=1âˆdiâ¢(z)ğ‘‘ğ‘§superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘§italic-d OPEN:( italic-z CLOSE:) RELOP:equals SUMOP:product POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-z CLOSE:)d(z)=\prod_{i=1}^{\infty}d_{i}(z) with one factor disubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endd_{i} for the family of eigenfunctions to which a given set of periodic orbits contributes. Each such factor diâ¢(z)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘§italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-z CLOSE:)d_{i}(z) is then calculated separately with the above well known expressions but restricting the periodic-orbit sum for the trace Trâ¢ğ’«nTrsuperscriptğ’«ğ‘›Tr caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\rm Tr}\;{\cal P}^{n} to the orbits previously identified as contributing to the eigenfunctions. In table 2 resonances reproduced via the spectral determinant from only few orbits show surprisingly good agreement with the resonance-eigenvalues of ğ’«(N)superscriptğ’«ğ‘caligraphic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( italic-N CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal P}^{(N)} for Ï„=10ğœ10italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:10\tau=10 and lmâ¢aâ¢x=60subscriptğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥60italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:60l_{max}=60. The index nmâ¢aâ¢xsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{max} gives the order up to which the spectral determinant is expanded, i.e. the length of the longest (pseudo-)orbits employed. The total number of orbits used is given in brackets behind the resonances. For the resonance 0.81030.8103NUMBER:0.81030.8103 the three relevant orbits of period 1,212NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:21,2 and 44NUMBER:44 are marked in the magnified region of the eigenfunction (lmâ¢aâ¢x=60subscriptğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥60italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:60l_{max}=60) in figure 2c. The first repetition of the single period-2-orbit contributing to the resonance 0.65970.6597NUMBER:0.65970.6597 gives an almost diverging contribution to the spectral determinant, thus hindering its expansion to a higher order.

In the cycle expansion the phases of the resonances are reproduced exactly since they are again directly determined by lengths of orbits. If pğ‘italic-pp is the shortest orbit length used in diâ¢(z)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘§italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-z CLOSE:)d_{i}(z), the polynomial can as well be written as a polynomial in zpsuperscriptğ‘§ğ‘italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endz^{p} thus allowing the zeros to have the phases of the pğ‘italic-ppth roots of unity.

As a final check on the physical meaning of our frozen eigenvalues with moduli smaller than unity as Frobenius-Perron resonances we have compared these moduli with rates of correlation decay. In a numerical experiment we investigated the decay of the correlator Câ¢(n)=[âŸ¨Ïâ¢(n)â¢Ïâ¢(0)âŸ©-âŸ¨Ïâ¢(âˆ)â¢Ïâ¢(0)âŸ©]â‹…[âŸ¨Ïâ¢(0)â¢Ïâ¢(0)âŸ©-âŸ¨Ïâ¢(âˆ)â¢Ïâ¢(0)âŸ©]-1ğ¶ğ‘›â‹…delimited-[]delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğœŒğ‘›ğœŒ0delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğœŒğœŒ0superscriptdelimited-[]delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğœŒ0ğœŒ0delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğœŒğœŒ01italic-C OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPEN:[ OPEN:langle italic-rho OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:) italic-rho OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle ADDOP:minus OPEN:langle italic-rho OPEN:( ID:infinity CLOSE:) italic-rho OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle CLOSE:] MULOP:cdot OPEN:[ OPEN:langle italic-rho OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) italic-rho OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle ADDOP:minus OPEN:langle italic-rho OPEN:( ID:infinity CLOSE:) italic-rho OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle CLOSE:] POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endC(n)\!=\![\langle\rho(n)\rho(0)\rangle-\langle\rho(\infty)\rho(0)\rangle]\cdot% [\langle\rho(0)\rho(0)\rangle-\langle\rho(\infty)\rho(0)\rangle]^{-1}. Depending on the choice of Ïâ¢(0)ğœŒ0italic-rho OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)\rho(0) different long-time decays are observable. We chose Ïâ¢(0)ğœŒ0italic-rho OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)\rho(0) as covering the regions where the hyperbolic orbits relevant for a given resonance are situated. Figure 1c illustrates the very good agreement between the long-time decay of Câ¢(n)ğ¶ğ‘›italic-C OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:)C(n) (dots) and the decay as predicted by the corresponding resonance 0.810.81NUMBER:0.810.81 (full line). Together with the resonances at lmâ¢aâ¢x=60subscriptğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥60italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:60l_{max}=60 table 2 displays the associated decay factors by which Câ¢(n)ğ¶ğ‘›italic-C OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:)C(n) decreases over one timestep, obtained from a numerical fit. Again the agreement is convincing.

In conclusion, we have presented a method to determine Frobenius-Perron resonances and the associated phase-space structures, applicable to systems with mixed phase spaces. The acquired knowledge of phase space structures allows to check the accuracy to which resonances are determined by the otherwise independent approaches of cycle expansion and correlation decay.

We are grateful to Shmuel Fishman for discussions initiating as well as accompanying this work. Support by the Sonderforschungsbereich â€œUnordnung und groÃŸe Fluktuationenâ€ and by the grant GAAV No. A1048804 of the Czech Academy of Sciences is thankfully acknowledged. F. H. also thanks the Isaac Newton Institute for hospitality during the workshop â€œSupersymmetry and Trace Formulaeâ€ in 1997 during which this work was begun; especially fruitful interactions with Ilya Goldscheid were made possible there.

figure.figcaption: Figure 1: (a) The eigenfunction to the almost unimodular eigenvalue 0.99930.9993NUMBER:0.99930.9993 for Ï„=4,lmâ¢aâ¢x=60formulae-sequenceğœ4subscriptğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥60italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:4 PUNCT:, italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:60\tau=4,l_{max}=60 is sharply localized on elliptic islands surrounding a period-33NUMBER:33-orbit in phase space. (b) Phase space portrait of the elliptic islands supporting the eigenfunction. (c) The decay of the correlator Câ¢(n)ğ¶ğ‘›italic-C OPEN:( italic-n CLOSE:)C(n) (dots) [with the initial density localized in the region shown in figure 2c] and the decay predicted by the corresponding resonance 0.81030.8103NUMBER:0.81030.8103 (full line) agree well (see also table 2).

Figure 2: Eigenfunction to the resonance-eigenvalue 0.810.81NUMBER:0.810.81 for Ï„=10ğœ10italic-tau RELOP:equals NUMBER:10\tau=10 and (a) lmâ¢aâ¢x=40subscriptğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥40italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:40l_{max}=40, (b) lmâ¢aâ¢x=60subscriptğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥60italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:60l_{max}=60. While the coarse structures are identical, finer structures appear in the eigenfunction with the higher resolution. (c) Magnification of the region of large amplitude in figure 2b. The numbers indicate the positions of the three periodic orbits of lengths 1,212NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:21,2 and 44NUMBER:44 which are used in the cycle expansion up to order nmâ¢aâ¢x=4subscriptğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥4italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:4n_{max}=4.
